columns.text: In this problem, we will determine whether the purchase of a new asset will be beneficial for the company.

The depreciation will be solved using the Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System where a specific factor will be multiplied to the initial cost to get the depreciation. 

The factors are:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Year 1}&=0.20\\
\text{Year 2}&=0.32\\
\text{Year 3}&=0.192\\
\text{Year 4}&=0.1152
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation for **Year 1** is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$385,000 \times 0.20\\[15 pt]
&=\$77,000
\end{aligned}$$

For Year 1, the depreciation is $\$77,000$

The depreciation for **Year 2** is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$385,000 \times 0.32\\[15 pt]
&=\$123,200
\end{aligned}$$

For Year 2, the depreciation is $\$123,200$

The depreciation for **Year 3** is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$385,000 \times 0.192\\[15 pt]
&=\$73,920
\end{aligned}$$

For Year 3, the depreciation is $\$73,920$

The depreciation for **Year 4** is:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$385,000 \times 0.1152\\[15 pt]
&=\$44,352
\end{aligned}$$

For Year 4, the depreciation is $\$44,352$

Substituting the depreciation to the formula for operating cash flow, we will get:

OCF for **Year 1**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow}&=\$145,000\times(1-0.22)\\
&+0.22 \times \$77,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$130,040
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for Years 1 to 3 are already given in the problem which is $\$3,100$. The net working capital at the start of the project is the initial investment in the inventory which amounts to $\$20,000$. 

Now, for the net working capital for Year 4, we will simply add all the values from the initial up to Year 3.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net working capital for Year 4}&=\$20,000+\$3,100\\
&+\$3,100+\$3,100\\[15 pt]
&=\$29,300
\end{aligned}$$

The net working capital for Year 4 is $\$29,300$

Another thing to solve for is the after-tax salvage value. Simply multiply the value at the end of the project by 1 minus the tax rate:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{After-tax salvage value}&=\$45,000 \times (1-0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$35,100
\end{aligned}$$

The after-tax salvage value of this machine is $\$35,100$

Simplifying, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value cash flow}&=\$451,058.64
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of the operating cash flow is $\$451,058.64$

Now that we have the necessary values, we can solve for the net present value using the formula in Step 2:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\$451,058.64-\$385,000-\$20,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$46,058.64
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value is $\$46,058.64$ which means that a change in the equipment should be made since it is beneficial and profitable to the company.
